div.p: In this study we investigated the melting and recrystallization of oriented tapes of isotactic polypropylene (iPP) under elevated pressure. Here we report some of the preliminary results. Figure 1 shows two X-ray patterns obtained under pressure of 650 bar and in a temperature scan which is relevant for the compaction technology previously suggested by the group 1 . Figure 1a displays the reflections of the original state which is the α crystalline form. It is possible to see that the original sample is highly oriented. From that point the sample was completely melted in two cycles. In each, the sample temperature reached the value of ~240 o C. Figure 1b displays the reflections of the final state. In that figure it is possible to see that there is a complete loss of orientation. In addition, there is a peak which corresponds to the γ crystalline form (hardly visible, but marked with a dashed line).

As was expected, the appearance of the γ form is getting more pronounced as the pressure under which the melting and recrystallization occurs gets higher. Figure 2 represents few Xray diffraction patterns of a sample which undergone two runs of heating until complete melting and cooling, under pressure of 2000 bar. The finger print of the γ form is clearly visible. In addition, it is possible to see that the height of that peak from the second run is lower than that obtained from the first run (relatively to their base lines). This phenomenon is clearer in Figure 3, which represents the relative content of the γ form compared to the α form as a function of the compaction pressure. The content was calculated from the empirical relation 2 :

div.p: Where h α , h γ are the heights of the (130) peak of the α form and the (117) peak of the γ form, respectively, measured from a base line. Suprisingly, the γ form content as a functin of pressure in the first cycle exhibits a minimum, while we expected a constant increase of the content with the pressure 3, 4 . Furthermore, a differnce in the content between the first run and the second run is clearly observed. The highly oriented state of the original tapes can suggest the reason for that difference: the first run creates an unoriented state from a highly oriented one. Therefore, the second run starts and ends in unoriented state. Since orientation leads to prefered formation of the γ form, which until now was observed only in injection molding 5 , we expected that the first run will lead to a higher content of the γ form. Analysis of the melting and crystallization processes under pressure is currently in progress.
